numbers¶

Included in swix/numbers.swift

numbers.DOUBLE_EPSILON = 'smaller'¶

The smallest possible difference between two doubles. See machine epsilon for more detail.

numbers.FLOAT_EPSILON = 'small'¶

The smallest possible difference between two floats. See machine epsilon for more detail.

numbers.PYTHON_PATH = '~/anaconda/bin/ipython'¶

Where is Python found? Used for imshow and savefig (testing on MacOSX only!). Assumes pylab is installed.

numbers.S2_PREFIX = '\\(NSHomeDirectory())/Developer/swix/swix/swix/swix/'¶

The path that should point to the swix directory. The file imshow.py, numbers.swix would be found by appending to this path.

numbers.close(x, y)¶
Parameters:
  • x – Double. An input value.
  • y – Double. Another value.
Return type:

Bool. True only if the two values are close numerically.

Specifically, true only if \(|x-y|<10^{-9}\).

>>> assert(close(0, 1e-10) == true)
numbers.convience_elements()¶

The built in class numeric classes has convience elements.

  • {Float|Double|Int|CInt}.int. Returns the integer value
  • {Float|Double|Int|CInt}.float. The floating point value
  • {Float|Double|Int|CInt}.double. The double value.
  • String.floatValue, String.doubleValue. Converts the string to a numeric value by interpetting a NSString.
  • String.nsstring. For interfacing with C.

Additionally, Int has an element cint, Double has element cdouble, Float has element cfloat.

>>> assert(3.14.int == 3)
>>> assert("3.14".floatValue == 3.14)
numbers.e = 2.718281828459045¶

Euler’s number

numbers.euler = 0.5772156649015329¶

Euler’s constant

numbers.inf = inf¶

Infinity.

numbers.isNumber(x)¶
Parameters:x – AnyObject.
Return type:Bool. True only if x is a number (a float, double, cint, int). Returns false for ndarray and matrix.
numbers.operator_slash(lhs, rhs)¶

The operator / that represents division. Converts integer division to floating point division.

Parameters:
  • lhs – Int.
  • rhs – Int.
Return type:

Double = lhs / rhs
numbers.phi = 1.618033988749895¶

The golden ratio Also callable with φ

numbers.pi = 3.141592653589793¶

The classic circle constant. Also called π

ndarray¶

Found in swix/ndarray/

ndarray_docs.argwhere(idx)¶
Parameters:idx (ndarray) – An array of 0’s and 1’s (analagous to true and false).
Return type:ndarray. Returns the indices where idx has non-zero elements.
ndarray_docs.println(x, prefix='array([', postfix='])', newline='\n', format='%.3f', seperator=', ', printWholeMatrix=False)¶
Parameters:x (ndarray) – Prints that matrix.

Prints the ndarray with the above optional formatters. They are all of type String.

Also callable: print(x, ..., newline="") with the same options.

ndarray class¶

Yes, an actual class (or struct).

class ndarray_docs.ndarray¶
copy()¶
Return type:ndarray. An exact copy of the array. 
>>> assert(x.copy() ~== x)
count = 'Int'¶

Number of elements.

grid = '[Double]'¶

The Array this ndarray depends on.

indexing(idx)¶
Parameters:idx (Int, Range<Int>, ndarray) – The values to get the index from. 
>>> var x = arange(10)
>>> assert(x[1] == 1)
>>> assert(x[0..<2] ~== array(0, 1))
>>> assert(x[array(0, 1)] ~== array(0, 1))
max()¶
Return type:Double. The maximum value in the array. 
>>> assert(array(1, 2, 3, 4).max() == 4)
mean()¶
Return type:Double. The mean value in the array. 
>>> assert(array(1, 2, 3, 4).mean() == 2.5)
min()¶
Return type:Double. The minimum value in the array. 
>>> assert(array(1, 2, 3, 4).min() == 1)

Number of elements this array contains

reshape(shape)¶
Parameters:shape ((Int, Int)) – The size of the new matrix.
Return type:matrix. The ndarray reshaped as a matrix. 
>>> x = arange(2*2).reshape((2,2))
>>> println(x)
# prints [0 1; 2 3]

initing¶

class ndarray_docs.initing¶
arange(max, min=0, x=True)¶
Parameters:
  • max (Int) – How high should the array index up to?
  • min (Int) – Where should the indexing start?
  • x (Bool) – Should the array be exclusive?
 
>>> assert(arange(2) ~== array(0, 1))
>>> assert(arange(4, 6) ~== array(4, 5))
>>> assert(arange(2, x:true) ~== array(0, 1, 2))
array(numbers)¶
Parameters:numbers (Double...) – A list of numbers to make an array.

Note

Unoptimized. I assume this is only being used in test code.

>>> println(array(0, 1, 2, 3, 4))
# prints array([0.000, 1.000, 2.000, 3.000, 4.000])

repeat(x, N, how='ndarray')¶
Parameters:
  • x (ndarray) – The array to repeat.
  • N (Int) – How many times to repeat the array.
  • how (String) – Assumed to be “ndarray” or “elements”.
 
>>> var x = array(0, 1)
>>> assert(repeat(x, 2, how:"ndarray") ~== array(0, 1, 0, 1))
>>> assert(repeat(x, 2, how:"elements") ~== array(0, 0, 1, 1))
toArray(sequence)¶
Parameters:sequence (Range<Int>) – A range of numbers.
Return type:ndarray. The sequence converted to an array. 
>>> assert(toArray(0..<2) ~== array(0, 1))
write_csv(x, filename, prefix='\(NSHomeDirectory())/Developer/swix/swix/swix/swix/')¶
Parameters:
  • x (ndarray) – The ndarray to write to a csv
  • filename (String) – Where to write.
  • prefix (String) – Defaults to S2_PREFIX. Writes to the folder above S2_PREFIX.

Note

Unoptimized. I assume you’re only using this on MacOSX to test your app.

operators¶

class ndarray_docs.operators¶
add_subtract_multiply_divide(lhs, rhs)¶
Parameters:
  • lhs (ndarray, Double) – Left hand side.
  • rhs (ndarray, Double) – Right hand side.

The operators + - * / % += -= *= /= < > <= >= == !== all work element wise and act similar to scalars.

Note

Callable through the natural operators (+, -, etc).

Note

== and !== see when two arrays are exactly equal for the incredibly percise doubles. I recommend using abs(x-y)<1e-9.

equality(lhs, rhs)¶
Parameters:
  • lhs (ndarray, Double) – Left hand side.
  • rhs (ndarray, Double) – Right hand side.

Sees if two arrays are approximately equal.

The comparison operators are all implemented through OpenCV and rely on the array being continuous in memory, which relies on having small input arrays. It will print (but not assert) if this is not the case.

Note

Callable through the ~== operator.

Note

To be changed to ~=.

>>> assert(array(0, 1) ~== array(0, 1+1e-10))
power(lhs, rhs)¶
Parameters:
  • lhs (ndarray) – The ndarray
  • rhs (Double.) – The power.
Return type:

ndarray, pow(lhs, rhs).

Note

Optimized for rhs=2. If close(2, rhs) == True, prints message but no assert.

>>> assert(array(1, 4) ~== array(1, 2)^2)

  • y (ndarray) – Another array.

>>> assert(max(array(0, 1, 5), array(2, 1, 0)) ~== array(2, 1, 5))

  • y (ndarray) – Another array.

  • power (Double) – The power

ndarray. Performs the same action as the operator ^. Raises each element to a power.

 
>>> assert(pow(array(1, 2, 3), 2) ~== array(1, 4, 9))

ndarray. Random integers normally distributed.

The seed stays constant for each call.

fft(x)¶
Parameters:x (ndarray) – An array to perform the fft on.
Return type:ndarray, ndarray. The real and imaginary components of the Fourier transform. 
>>> x = arange(10)
>>> assert(x ~== ifft(fft(x)))

Parameters:
  • y_real (ndarray) – The real part of fft(x).
  • y_imag (ndarray) – The imaginary part of fft(x)
Return type:

ndarray. The inverse Fourier transform of \(y_{real} + j \cdot y_{imag}\)

class matrix_docs.matrix¶

Returns the inverse of the matrix.

Returns the transpose of the matrix.

copy()¶

>>> x = arange(4).reshape((2,2))
>>> assert(x ~== x.copy())
flat = 'ndarray'¶

The base ndarray stored in row-major order.

index(one, two)¶
Parameters:
  • one (Int, Range<Int>, ndarray) – The row selector.
  • two (Int, Range<Int>, ndarray) – The column selector.
Return type:

matrix

 
>>> x = arange(9).reshape((3,3))
# x = [0 1 2; 3 4 5; 6 7 8]
>>> assert(x[0,1] == 1)
>>> assert(x[0..<2, 0..<3] ~== array("0 1 2; 3 4 5")
>>> assert(x[arange(2), arange(3)] ~== array("0 1 2; 3 4 5")

Parameters:string (String) – This asserts that this input string must be “diag”.
Return type:ndarray

Gets or sets the diagonal of a matrix.

Parameters:idx (ndarray) – In row major order, the elements to take.
Return type:ndarray. Indexes matrix.flat in row-major order. 
>>> x = arange(9).rehshape((3,3))
>>> assert(x[array(0, 3, 6)] ~== array(0, 3, 6))

initing¶

class matrix_docs.initing¶
array(matlab_like_string)¶
Parameters:matlike_like_string –
Return type:matrix

Interpets the string as a matrix, matlab style. ; is interpets as a new row.

Warning

This currently only works with one digit positive numbers. Negative numbers and multiple digit numbers throw it for a loop. I would recommend using array(Double...).reshape((M,N)) instead.

>>> assert(array("1 2; 3 4") ~== array(1, 2, 3, 4).reshape((2,2))
copy(x, y)¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The source matrix.
  • y (matrix) – The destination matrix.

Modifies y to contain exactly x.

Warning

This function is deprecated. Don’t use it!

diag(x)¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – A matrix.
Return type:ndarray

Returns the diagonal of an array.

Warning

This function is deprecated.

eye(N)¶
Parameters:N (Int) – The size of the array will be N x N
Return type:matrix. An identity matrix.
meshgrid(x, y)¶
Parameters:
  • x (ndarray) – One set of elements.
  • y (ndarray) – Another set of elements.
Return type:

(matrix, matrix).

This function evaulates every possible combination of x and y. Very similar to NumPy’s meshgrid.

>>> x, y = meshgrid(array(1, 2), array(3, 4))
>>> println(x)
# prints [1 2; 1 2]
>>> println(y)
# prints [3 3; 4 4]

Operators¶

class matrix_docs.operators¶
dot(x, y)¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The lhs.
  • y (matrix) – The rhs
Return type:

matrix.

Performs a matrix multiplication between two matrices.

Note

Also callable through *! and x.dot(y)

element_operators(lhs, rhs)¶
Parameters:
  • lhs (Double, matrix) – The left hand side
  • rhs (Double, matrix) – The right hand side

The operators + - * / % += -= *= /= < > <= >= == !== all work element wise and act similar to scalars.

Note

Callable through the natural operators (+, -, etc).

Note

== and !== see when two arrays are exactly equal for the incredibly percise doubles. I recommend using abs(x-y)<1e-9.

equailty(x, y)¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) –
  • y (matrix) –
Return type:

Bool. true only if the two arrays are approximately equal.
solve(A, b)¶
Parameters:
  • A (matrix) – When multplied with x, this is what the equation equals.
  • b (ndarray) – What the equation equals.
Return type:

ndarray

Solves for x in \(Ax=b\). The same as right-multiplying by the inverse but much faster.

Note

Only works for N x N matrices. Doesn’t have a least squares solution yet.

Note

Also callable through !/

sum(x, dim=-1)¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) –
  • dim (Int) – Assumed to be either 0 or 1. Takes all the values in dim and sums them. A value is in a certain dimension if changing that indexing argument selects a different value.
Return type:

ndarray

 
>>> var x = arange(6).reshape((2,3))
>>> assert(sum(x, dim:0) ~== array(3, 12))
>>> assert(sum(x, dim:1) ~== array(3, 5, 7))

Images¶

class matrix_docs.images¶
imshow(x)¶
Parameters:x (matrix) – The matrix you want to see.

Shows the matrix. Relies on Python being found at PYTHON_PATH and pylab stack being installed

rgb2hsv(r, g, b)¶
Parameters:
  • r (matrix) – The red color plane.
  • g (matrix) – The green color plane.
  • b (matrix) – The blue color plane.
Return type:

(matrix, matrix, matrix). Returns the HSV color planes.

Note

This function isn’t optimized. If you want to go fast, look at only including the V plane and using max.

savefig(x, filename, save=True, show=False)¶
Parameters:
  • x (matrix) – The matrix you want to see.
  • filename (String) – The filename you want to save at.

Saves the matrix. Relies on Python being found at PYTHON_PATH and pylab stack being installed

Machine learning¶

class machine_learning_docs.SVM¶

example:

>>> var svm = SVM()

>>> # our responses. 
>>> var responses = reshape(ones(2*3), (2, 3))

>>> #/ OpenCV can fail for too similar inputs (probably synthetic)
>>> for i in 0..3{
>>>     responses[1][i] = -1
>>> }

>>> #/ our targets.
>>> var targets = ones(2); targets[1] = -1

>>> #/ train with responses
>>> svm.train(responses, targets: targets)

>>> #/ predict
>>> var y = -1 * ones(3) // must have same size!
>>> var result = svm.predict(y)
M = 'number of responses'¶

The number of responses.

N = 'number of variables in a response'¶

The number of variables.

kernel_type = 'kernel type'¶

Useful in mapping to a nonlinear function.

predict(responses)¶
Parameters:responses (matrix, ndarray) – The response to some unknown variable.
Return type:ndarray, Double
setParams(svm_type, kernel, nu=0.5)¶
Parameters:
  • svm_type (String) – Assumed to be either C_SVC, ONE_CLASS, NU_SVC or NU_SVR
  • kernel (String) – Assumed to be one of LIENAR or SIGMOID

Sets the parameters for the SVM.

svm_type = 'SVM type'¶

Can drastically change performance.

train(responses, targets)¶
Parameters:
  • resonses – The matrix of responses to some (known!) variable.
  • targets (ndarray) – The known variables a response is associated with.
class machine_learning_docs.kNearestNeighbors¶

Warning

My simple test failed.

M = 'responses'¶

the number of variables in a response

N = 'variables'¶

the number of variables you train for

predict(x, k)¶
Parameters:
  • x (ndarray) – The reponse you want to train for.
  • k (Int) – The number of neighest neighbors you want to train against.
Return type:

Double. The predicted response.
train(responses, targets)¶
Parameters:
  • responses (matrix) – The responses.
  • targets (ndarray) – The targets you know exist.

Interfacing with C¶

c_docs.matrixToPointer(x)¶
Parameters:x (ndarray, [Int]) – The ndarray you want to take the address of.
Return type:UnsafeMutablePointer<Double>. Equivalent to double *

Note

If you want pointer to matrix, use matrixToPointer(x.flat)

Note

Callable through operator !x for both ndarray and matrix.

c_docs.pointerTo2DMatrix(xPC, N)¶
Parameters:
  • N (CInt) – Int
  • M (CInt) – Int
  • xPC (UnsafeMutablePointer<Double>) – The pointer to the first element of the matrix
Return type:

matrix

Warning

I recommend initalizing some array then passing !x to a C function. This seems dangerous.

c_docs.pointerToMatrix(xPC, N)¶
Parameters:
  • N (CInt) – Int
  • xPC (UnsafeMutablePointer<Double>) – The pointer to the first element of the matrix
Return type:

ndarray

Warning

I recommend initalizing some array then passing !x to a C function. This seems dangerous.

Tips¶

  • Use .cint, .cfloat, .cdouble to pass numeric values to C.
